subject: Art
title: Phone Photography
description: The best camera is the one you have ‚Äî mastering your smartphone.

hook.text: The best camera is the one in your pocket. Modern smartphones have incredible cameras ‚Äî and you always have yours with you. Learning to use it well matters more than owning expensive gear you leave at home.

buildup.text: Phone strengths: always available, lightweight, wide-angle lens, instant sharing, powerful computational photography (HDR, night mode, portrait mode). Phone weaknesses: small sensor (noise in low light), limited optical zoom, less control.

discovery.text: Phone pro tips: clean the lens (fingerprints kill sharpness), tap to set focus AND exposure point, use the grid overlay, avoid digital zoom (walk closer instead), use volume buttons as shutter, and explore Pro/Manual mode.

twist.text: Computational photography is phones' secret weapon: HDR merges multiple exposures for dynamic range. Night mode combines dozens of frames for low-light clarity. These algorithmic tricks increasingly rival expensive cameras.

climax.text: Challenge: take your phone and spend 30 minutes shooting ONE subject using different angles, distances, and light. You'll prove that limitation breeds creativity. Great photos come from great seeing, not great gear.

punchline.text: The camera doesn't make the photograph. You do. Use what you have.

quiz.question: What is computational photography's main advantage for smartphones?
options: It combines multiple frames algorithmically to overcome the phone's small sensor limitations
It only works with specific apps
It replaces the need for lenses
